2017$[RANGE] https://www.flickr.com/groups/automobilia/$Colin and Carole Vincent$http://newquaytown.com/automobilia-motor-museum-st-stephens-cornwall$/Transport/Cars and motorbikes$$Unaccredited$$/Independent/Private$$$$$$unknown$Automobilia is housed on three floors of a fine old 19th century watermill and two outbuildings. It aims to give shape and structure to the development of the motor car from the horseless carriages of 1904 to the classic sports cars of the 60 s.     Unusually, the top floor of the cars main showcase is dedicated to Autojumble - a kind of veterans parts warehouse where elusive components may be found to complete a restoration, or encourage a new beginning. An audio-visual presentation traces the history of the collection and explains the extraordinary mixture of dedication, coincidence and piece-by-piece restoration] that have saved the older cars for posterity.     Each car on display is there on merit - for its popularity, eccentricity or originality in engineering or construction. And naturally there are stars - a Marendaz, a Skinner Union, a one-off Bentley from W.Os heyday - which makes this a must for all true enthusiasts.      Displays of motoring memorabilia spice the main exhibits and a large number of reproduction and modern motoring accessories can be purchased in the museum shop in Reception.     Alternatively, the Grille Room on the ground-floor of the Mill offers the chance to sit down and discuss the exhibits over a home-made cake, a hot snack or full meal.   Read more: http://newquaytown.com/automobilia-motor-museum-st-stephens-cornwall#ixzz4h9rmGEIr     Automobilia is housed on three floors of a fine old 19th century watermill and two outbuildings. It aims to give shape and structure to the development of the motor car from the horseless carriages of 1904 to the classic sports cars of the 60s.     Unusually, the top floor of the cars main showcase is dedicated to Autojumble - a kind of veterans parts warehouse where elusive components may be found to complete a restoration, or encourage a new beginning. An audio-visual presentation traces the history of the collection and explains the extraordinary mixture of dedication, coincidence and piece-by-piece restoration] that have saved the older cars for posterity.     Each car on display is there on merit - for its popularity, eccentricity or originality in engineering or construction. And naturally there are stars - a Marendaz, a Skinner Union, a one-off Bentley from W.Os heyday - which makes this a must for all true enthusiasts.      Displays of motoring memorabilia spice the main exhibits and a large number of reproduction and modern motoring accessories can be purchased in the museum shop in Reception.     Alternatively, the Grille Room on the ground-floor of the Mill offers the chance to sit down and discuss the exhibits over a home-made cake, a hot snack or full meal.   Read more: http://newquaytown.com/automobilia-motor-museum-st-stephens-cornwall#ixzz4h9rmGEIr $$

9999$http://www.bromsgroveadvertiser.co.uk/news/local/14526099.Bromsgrove_museum_reopened_after_eight_years/$$$/Mixed/Bygones$social history$Unaccredited$$/Independent/Not for profit$$$$$$very_small$$Collection assembled by Dennis Norton and opened as a museum in 1979. Norton decided that best way to safeguard the museum was to transfer it to the local authority, which happened in 1992. Visitor numbers decreased and the local authority decided to close the museum in 2008. Lengthy negotiations took place between the Council and Norton and ultimately a trust was setup and the council agreed to sell the building and collections to the Trust. The museum re-opened in 2016. Previously known as Bromsgrove Museum.$

1990$mm155$$$/Rural Industry/Farming$$Unaccredited$$/Government/Local Authority$$$$$$unknown$r.e. governance: During Harold Wilsons second term as prime minister the Civic Trust obtained a grant from the EU and developed the Pennine Farm Museum which opened in 1975...The museum was open 7 days a week in the beginning but this gradually reduced, someone who lived at the bottom of Old Bank kept it going but I cant remember his name... By 1990 the owner, Ian Beaumont, wanted to sell it so it closed and all the contents went to Bankfield museum.  Eventually Calderdale took it over and by 1986 it was only open on Sunday or by appointment   When museum closed collections went to Bankfield Museum (mm155)$$

(Devolved 2015 - There is a history of museum collections in the town since 1932 and it appears that a museum was opened to the public in 1939. The museum moved to its current premises in 1996 (the year of foundation given in the domus data). The collections appear to be owned by the Herne Bay Historical Records Society and the museum was operated by this group until 1996. At this point it seems that the collections were loaned to Canterbury City Council who administered the museum (but there is also an indication that the Council own some of the collection). In 2015 the Herne Bay Museum Trust had their tender accepted by the Council to manage and operate the museum). Previously known as Herne Bay Museum and Gallery (changed in 2015)$

1988$https://www.flickr.com/photos/chrisengland/sets/72157632452170888/$$$/Transport/Aviation$$Unaccredited$$/Independent/Private$$$$$$unknown$Postcode an approximation of where museum used to be. from Domesday Reloaded. 1986. Torbay Aircraft Museum is a collection of warplanes, helicopters, anti-aircraft guns, uniforms and small weapons.                              First it showed the Dam Busters, behind a glass cabinet was a model of a Lancaster bomber. It then showed us   the effect of a bouncing bomb on a dam wall. Then there was a real bouncing bomb.                                   There were many uniforms and relics from World War II, as well as World     War I.                                  Outside the Museum were the aeroplanes  that flew in the Battle of Britain.     Many tourists visit the Museum, one     of the many tourist attractions to be   found in and around Torbay.$$
